A standard OR gate behaves such that the output is powered ("+") if at least one of its inputs is powered ("+"), and it is not powered ("-") only if all of its inputs are not powered ("-"). For a single-input OR gate, the output would trivially be the same as the input. However, for a two-input OR gate, the operation can be visualized as follows:

- If I1 is powered ("+") and I2 is powered ("+"), then O will be powered ("+").
- If I1 is powered ("+") and I2 is not powered ("-"), then O will be powered ("+").
- If I1 is not powered ("-") and I2 is powered ("+"), then O will be powered ("+").
- If I1 is not powered ("-") and I2 is not powered ("-"), then O will be not powered ("-").

Thus, the circuit diagram for a two-input OR gate can be formatted as:

```
[[I1, I2, O]; ["+", "+", "+"]; ["+", "-", "+"]; ["-", "+", "+"]; ["-", "-", "-"]]
```
